Fix time format issue in task storage and parsing
commitResults.messageBody:
The current time format for deadlines and events in the task storage file is inconsistent. Times like ‘0200’ are being saved as ‘200’, which leads to parsing errors when reloading tasks.

This needs to change because the inconsistent format causes the application to fail when attempting to parse times without leading zeros. Using an incorrect format affects the ability of the program to read and write date-time values correctly, which leads to crashes.

Change the DateTimeFormatter to use the format yyyy-MM-dd HHmm for both saving and parsing tasks. Ensure that all times are stored in a consistent format with leading zeros, preventing parsing errors when reading tasks back from the file.

This solution is chosen because it enforces a standardized format for date and time, which avoids ambiguity and ensures compatibility with the LocalDateTime parser in Java. By using a format that includes leading zeros, the program can consistently handle and display dates and times without issues.

Also, update the task storage file to reflect the new format to avoid further parsing problems.

commitResults.messageTitle: Utilize Ui.showLoadingError and Ui.showWelcome methods in MainWindow for better user feedback
commitResults.messageBody:
The showLoadingError() and showWelcome() methods in the Ui class were previously unused, resulting in missed opportunities to provide user feedback when tasks failed to load or when the application started.

This needs to change because displaying a welcome message upon startup enhances the user experience by introducing the application. Additionally, informing users of errors, such as task loading failures, is critical to ensure transparency and guide users in case of issues.

The showWelcome() method is now used in the MainWindow class’s initialize() method to display a welcome message when the application starts. The showLoadingErrorInGui() method was added to MainWindow and is used to handle task-loading failures, ensuring the error is displayed in the graphical interface rather than just the console.

This approach ensures that the GUI provides clear feedback to users at critical points—during startup and when errors occur—improving both usability and error handling in the application.
